body: @shalomma @LarsHill would either of you be interested in working on this feature? If so I'm happy to write up / help collaborate on an API proposal :)
@smurching sorry, but in the near future I won't have time working on it. I just thought it would be a useful feature.
@smurching are you working on it ? I will be happy to help :)

@pierrelandry I haven't worked on it, that'd be awesome! Before writing code & opening a PR, a good first step would be to write up a description of the proposed API & its behavior. Happy to review a proposal if you're able to write one & share it here.

I'm new to Pytorch, but I'd recommend focusing on adding autologging for the most common Pytorch APIs first (will spend some time tomorrow learning more about Pytorch). Also, I'd suggest `mlflow.pytorch.autolog()` as the API name, to match the existing Keras & TF autologging APIs, but open to alternatives. Thanks for being willing to contribute :)!
@pierrelandry hope you enjoyed the holidays! Thanks again for your interest in helping with this - are you still interested in collaborating?

Hi, I'd love to work on the fastai integration, is there any proposed API?
I thought of adding support for logging metrics during training and saving artifacts generated from
[SaveModelCallback](https://docs.fast.ai/callbacks.html#SaveModelCallback) or [Learner.save](https://docs.fast.ai/basic_train.html#Learner.save) method.

@antoniomdk sorry for the delayed response, that'd be awesome - one strawman API proposal would be to add an `mlflow.pytorch.autolog()` API, and an `mlflow.fastai.autolog()` if appropriate - AFAICT fastai & PyTorch are analogous to Keras and TensorFlow (fastai seems to be a higher-level API implemented using PyTorch), so seems reasonable to have separate APIs for the two libraries. 

That being said, it's probably worth considering whether implementing PyTorch autologging could indirectly solve fastai autologging (i.e. could we reuse the implementation of PyTorch autologging for fastai autologging?). My guess is that it might be possible, but the right way to implement fastai autologging would be instead be to use public `fastai` APIs, e.g. by adding callbacks to save & log the user's model as you described - I don't know too much about either PyTorch or fastai so curious to hear your opinion.

Yes, you're right, Fastai is a higher-level API on top of Pytorch as Keras is on top of Tensorflow. Adding model saving autologging for Pytorch would solve it also for Fastai, as the latter relies on torch.save
https://github.com/fastai/fastai/blob/master/fastai/basic_train.py#L246
So, monkey patching [torch.save](https://pytorch.org/docs/stable/torch.html?highlight=save#torch.save) would work for both libraries. It'd also work for model checkpoints along epochs. 

On the other hand, I think we should go for adding a callback to handle metric logging on Fastai.
There is also a proposal from the Fastai community to add a callback for this: https://forums.fast.ai/t/mlflow-tracking-support/38893

For Pytorch I'm not sure how we should proceed because the training cycle is done manually and the evaluation depends on the user implementing it.

Adding autologging to PyTorch is much harder inherently because PyTorch's training cycle can be very flexible and can take many forms, like @antoniomdk mentioned. I took a look at what MLFlow autologging does for other frameworks (https://www.mlflow.org/docs/latest/tracking.html#automatic-logging-from-tensorflow-and-keras-experimental), and I think we might be able to do the following:

- Metrics

| Logging Item | Possible Implementation |
| ------------- | ------------- |
| training loss  | Monkey-patch [Tensor.backward](https://pytorch.org/docs/stable/autograd.html#torch.Tensor.backward) method and log the tensor |
| validation loss  | (This is difficult to track because we can't know programmatically which variable is the validation loss. We might have to resort to manual logging.) |
| user-specified metrics | (Not sure how we should map this concept from Keras to PyTorch.) |

- Parameters

| Logging Item | Possible Implementation |
| ------------- | ------------- |
| fit() parameters  | (Not sure how we should map this concept from Keras to PyTorch.) |
| optimizer name  | Find instantiations of [torch.optim.Optimizer](https://pytorch.org/docs/stable/optim.html#torch.optim.Optimizer) subclasses in the code, and log the optimizer name |
| learning rate | Log the `lr` value of the optimizer found above |
| epsilon | Log the `eps` value of the optimizer found above |

- Artifacts

| Logging Item | Possible Implementation |
| ------------- | ------------- |
| model summary on training start | Monkey-patch `Tensor.backward` or `Optimizer.step` method and log the model summary on the first method call |
| MLFlow model (PyTorch model) on training end | The end of training is hard to detect, but maybe we can monkey-patch `Optimizer.step` or `torch.nn.Module.eval` method to trigger MLFlow model saving after every epoch |

> AFAICT fastai & PyTorch are analogous to Keras and TensorFlow (fastai seems to be a higher-level API implemented using PyTorch), so seems reasonable to have separate APIs for the two libraries.

+1 I think it's easier to add autologging to fastai as a separate API because callbacks are a cleaner way to implement autologging.

I think it'd be hard to detect the last epoch using Optimizer.step or torch.nn.Module.eval.
For model persistence it's easier to rely on [torch.save](https://pytorch.org/docs/stable/torch.html?highlight=save#torch.save).

For optimizer tracking we can monkey-patch torch.optim.Optimizer class to keep track of all instances created. We can use those instances to log optimizer parameters, as @jacobhess118 suggested.

For tracking loss I'm not sure if using Tensor.backward would be a good idea (could it make Tensor.backward subcalls?).
